title: What is the point on ellipse 4x2+9y2=36 where normal is parallel to the line 4x-2y-5=0? - Quora

response.answer_text: Writing in standard form of ellipse, X^2/9+y^2/4=1 Normal to ellipse at (x1,y1) is a^2x/x1-b^2y/y1=a^2-b^2 This normal is parallel to the line 4x-2y=5 comparing the coefficient of x and y on both sides, 4/(a^2/x1)-2/(-b^2/y1)=5/a^2-b^2 Here a^2=9 and b^2=4, 4x1/9+2y1/4=5/(9–4) 4x1/9+2y1/4=1 16x1+18y1=36 Locus of (x1,y1) is 16x+18y=36 Dividing by 2 throughout, 8x+9y=18

The given ellipse can be written as : x²/9 + y²/4 = 1 …. .. ..(1). Any line which is || to the line 4x - 2y - 5 = 0 is given by 4x - 2y + k = 0 . If it is a normal line to the ellipse (1), then it must be comparable with the normal at any point P(3cost, 2sint) of the ellipse (1). But the normal at the point P is given as follows; (y - 2sint) = - (1/m)(x - 3cost), where m is slope of the tangent at the point P . Now, we have from (1), m = dy/dx at P. It ==> m = (-2/3)cot(t) which in turn gives (-1/m)= (3/2)tan(t) . Hence the equation of the normal line is : (y - 2sint) =(3/2)tan(t).(x - 3cost) or 2y - (3.tant)x + 5 sint = 0 …. .,,(2). Comparing it with 4x - 2y + k = 0 , we get, 2/-2 = 4/(-3tant) = k/5.sint . From the first two ratios , we get, tan(t) = 4/3 ==> cos(t) = (±3/5) and sin(t) = (±4/5). Therefore, the required points P are (3.(±3/5), 2.(±4/5) or =(9/5, 8/5), (-9/5, -8/5) . The two normal lines || to the given normal line are ; 4x - 2y ± 4 = 0 .
